I. 

THE ONGOING PROJECT 

1. 
The urban poor in Ulaanbaatar City are concentrated in the surrounding ger (traditional 
yurt or tent) areas, which are home to about 60% of the city’s population (800,000 inhabitants).   
As these low- and medium-income settlement areas continue to grow and densify from natural 
growth rate and immigration, the inadequacy of basic infrastructure services, as well as public 
spaces and commercial services, have become more serious. Responding to these urgent needs 
and demands for urban services, and the urgency to address ongoing densification in ger areas, 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  totaling 
$163.70  million  on  12  December  2013  for  the  Ulaanbaatar  Urban  Services  and  Ger  Areas 
Development  Investment  Program. 1  The  9-year  implementation  period  (December  2013–
December  2022)  comprises three tranches  of multisector  interventions that  support  delivery  of 
the  Ulaanbaatar  City  master  plan  in  upgrading  priority  infrastructure  services  and  developing 
economic hubs (subcenters) in ger areas. Tranche 1 of the MFF2 is supported by this technical 
assistance (TA) and focuses specifically on two priority subcenters of Bayankhoshuu and Selbe. 
The  expected  outcome  is  a  network  of  livable,  competitive,  and  inclusive  subcenters  in 
Ulaanbaatar’s ger areas; and the outputs include (i) roads and urban services are expanded within 
the  targeted  subcenters,  and  connectivity  between  them  is  improved;  (ii)  economic  and  public 
services in targeted subcenters are improved; (iii) service providers become more efficient; and 
(iv) institutions and capacity for urban development, program management, and service delivery 
are strengthened.    
 
2. 
The design of the MFF, and specifically of Tranche 1, took into account international best 
practices in the upgrading and redevelopment of urban areas. The investments were identified 
through mapping initiatives and were prioritized to improve access to basic infrastructure services 
for ger area residents. The interventions make significant efforts to engage and involve local ger 
residents  on  an  ongoing  basis  (from  design  to  implementation).  Consultations  and  public 
meetings  have  been  conducted  to  solicit  the  views  and  concerns  of  beneficiaries,  including 
women  and  vulnerable  groups,  and  integrate  these  into  the  detailed  design.  In  addition,  the 
MFF helps  build  social  fabric  and  improves  livelihood  potential  in  these  communities  through 
community-based organizations such as community development councils (CDCs) and small and 
medium-sized  enterprise  (SME)  development  councils  (SDCs).  These  efforts  help  enhance 
transparency  and  build  trust  among  relevant  stakeholders—the  community,  municipality,  and 
private sector—in support of the common goal of ger area redevelopment. 
 
3. 
Tranche 1 was approved on 17 December 2013 and became effective on 24 September 
2014. Procurement activities are well underway and all civil works are expected to be substantially 
completed by the loan closing date in December 2019. The program management office (PMO) 
is capable and performing well. The government’s commitment to, ownership of, and support for 
the program and its roadmap are high. 
 

                                                
1   ADB.  2013.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Multitranche 
Financing Facility to Mongolia for the Ulaanbaatar Urban Services and Ger Areas Development Investment Program. 
Manila.  

2   ADB.  2013.  Ulaanbaatar  Urban  Services  and  Ger  Areas  Development  Investment  Program:  Periodic  Financing 
Request 1. Manila. Tranche 1 includes a $27.5 million ordinary capital resources loan, a $22.5 million concessional 
ordinary capital resources loan, and a $3.7 million grant from the Urban Environmental Infrastructure Fund under the 
Urban  Financing  Partnership  Facility.  The  total  counterpart  funding  is  $96  million,  and  is  complemented  by  
$60.3 million in equivalent cofinancing from the European Investment Bank. 

 

 

 2 

A. 

Justification 

II. 

THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

to  apply 

International  experience  has  demonstrated  potential 

information  and 
4. 
communication technology (ICT) to urban upgrading and redevelopment efforts. In these projects, 
ICT solutions can offer support to (i) better collect and present data on physical infrastructure and 
socioeconomic  characteristics  of  urban  areas;  (ii)  facilitate  communication  and  trust-building 
among  the  government,  communities,  and  investors;  (iii)  enhance  and  expedite  information 
sharing  to  larger  audiences;  and  (iv)  better  monitor  and  present  development  results. 
Understanding  these  advantages,  the  Municipality  of  Ulaanbaatar  (MUB)  is  seeking  to  pilot 
appropriate ICT innovations  in  promoting redevelopment  of  Ulaanbaatar’s  ger  areas  at  a  small 
scale, before replicating success to all ger areas.  
 
5. 
Tranche 1 provides an ideal environment to pilot ICT applications for urban redevelopment 
in ger areas, thanks to the extensive preparation work carried out in urban planning, community 
engagement,  as  well  as  economic  and  infrastructure  development.  Under  Tranche  1, 
comprehensive data on the ger areas of Bayankhoshuu and Selbe subcenters has been collected 
through poverty analysis and mapping, community profile survey, community needs assessment, 
and business profile survey. Based on these data, block development methodology and land use 
plans have been formulated, subcenter infrastructure and spatial plans revised, and subcenter 
urban development and business plans developed. Community-based CDCs and SDCs in each 
subcenter  have  actively  engaged  the  local  ger  area  residents  to  formulate  community  and 
business action plans. The PMO has developed extensive experience in designing, implementing, 
and  monitoring  infrastructure  development  in  ger  areas  with  a  set  of  detailed  baseline  data. 
Together these achievements are a foundation of reliable data, rich content, and strong capacity 
to facilitate ICT applications. 

 
ICT  applications  will  not  only  benefit  from  the  readiness  under  Tranche  1  but  will  also 
6. 
contribute  to  enhance  the  development  objectives  of  Tranche  1.  The  TA  will  pilot  a  set  of 
customized ICT tools in the targeted ger areas, such as (i) an interactive mapping application for 
land  use  and  development  planning;  (ii)  ICT-supported  community  outreach  and  information 
disclosure;  (iii)  e-guidelines  and  support  for  SME  development;  (iv)  a  transparent  and  efficient 
platform to enhance awareness and visibility for ger areas infrastructure development, promote 
investment opportunities in ger areas, and enhance synergies among stakeholders in the public 
sector,  the  private  sector,  and  the  communities;  and  (v)  a  computerized  project  performance 
management system. These ICT tools will introduce innovative ways to carry out existing tasks 
and hopefully enhance efficiency and effectiveness of the Tranche 1 interventions. The linkages 
between TA outputs and development objectives of Tranche 1 are detailed below. 

 
In  April  2017,  the  MUB  submitted  a  request  for  support  from  ADB  and  the  Republic  of 
7. 
Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  to  pilot  ICT  applications  for  ger  area 
redevelopment  activities  under  Tranche  1.  Since  this  request  came  after  the  approval  of  the 
country operations business plan (COBP) for Mongolia, 2017–2019,3 the TA was not included in 
the COBP. The funding from the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for 
this TA was approved on 1 June 2017. 
 

                                                
3  ADB. 2017.  Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2017–2019. Manila. The COBP was published in April 

2017. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 October 2017.  

 

 B. 

Outputs and Activities  

8. 
The TA will pilot ICT tools for ger area redevelopment in (i) enhancing municipality-level 
urban  and  redevelopment  planning  with  mapping  and  monitoring  indicators  (output  1); 
(ii) supporting  inclusive  community  engagement  and  access  to  economic  opportunities  in  ger 
areas,  (outputs  2  and  3);  and  (iii)  strengthening  redevelopment  monitoring  and  coordination 
capacity (output 4).  
 
Output 1: Ger area urban and redevelopment planning enhanced. Building on the rich 
9. 
data  collected  through  mapping  exercises  under  Tranche  1,  this  TA  will  apply  easy-to-use 
ICT tools to map physical and socioeconomic characteristics of selected ger areas to enhance 
data quality and presentation. The information collected will be integrated with the existing urban 
database  in  Ulaanbaatar.  In  addition,  expert  recommendations  will  be  provided  to  MUB  to  
(i) enhance the urban database with key indicators to support evidence-based planning, (ii) create 
a monitoring mechanism for eco-district development for green housing and infrastructure, and 
(iii) integrate appropriate ICT outputs into future infrastructure investments.  
 
10. 
Output 2: Community engagement process supported. Effective communication and 
information sharing have been recognized as being key in enhancing transparency and building 
trust between government and residents. The MFF has made significant efforts in this regard by 
working with CDCs, which are well-positioned to act as community conveners. This output will 
support efforts under the Tranche 1 by providing customized community outreach activities—both 
physical and virtual—to engage the community with the project. These activities will take place at 
business  incubator  centers  (BICs)  to  be  constructed  for  the  Bayankhoshuu  and  Selbe 
subcenters.4  This output will also develop a virtual platform to facilitate community action planning 
(e.g., for urban upgrading, feedback, and grievance redress mechanisms), and place ICT kiosks 
in  BICs  for  access  by  and  use  of  ger  area  residents.  The  platform  and activities  will  take  into 
consideration the specific characteristics of the ger area community in order to reach the widest 
possible audience and help them mobilize and learn together as a community. This will leverage 
the thriving community of nongovernment organizations in Ulaanbaatar, especially women’s and 
youth groups.  
  
Output  3:  Business  and  investment  development  support  services  in  ger  areas 
11. 
enhanced. Tranche 1 has a provision to help create economic opportunities in ger areas, focusing 
on demand (by raising investment interest among investors), and supply (by building the relevant 
skills, both vocational and entrepreneurial, of ger residents). This output will build on Tranche 1 
activities  to  provide  (i)  prioritized  ICT-based  support  under  BICs,  including  e-guidelines  for 
selected government services; (ii) integrated support for SMEs, including ICT and business skills 
training, hands-on coaching, and networking; (iii) a virtual platform to connect independent skilled 
labor in ger areas with prospective employers; and (iv) a clearinghouse to promote investment 
opportunities  in  ger  areas.  ICT  solutions  can  help  provide  up-to-date  information  to  potential 
investors or those looking for goods and services from  ger areas, or any other opportunities to 
support the redevelopment process. Improved information availability will help build trust among 
investors and ger residents to take part in economic development activities and contribute to the 
redevelopment plan initiated under the MFF. ICT solutions will allow the centers to reach a larger 
audience, in particular younger entrepreneurs and start-ups with innovative and bankable ideas. 
It  will  adopt  and  learn  from  the  Asia  Foundation’s  Women  Business  Incubator  Center  model, 

                                                
4  The plan is to turn the BICs into multipurpose community centers that will provide community engagement activities, 

business incubator services, and subcenter redevelopment information services. 

3 

 

 which  has  been  transferred  to  and  is  operated  by  MUB,  to  especially  support  female 
entrepreneurs. 
 
12. 
Output  4:  Ger  area  redevelopment  monitoring  and  coordination  strengthened. 
ICT can support MUB to strengthen monitoring of redevelopment efforts through the application 
of  a  modern  computerized  project  performance  management  system,  as  well  as  e-tools  to 
streamline  coordination  among  stakeholders  involved  in  the  Tranche  1  targeted  areas  (e.g., 
government agencies, donors, and nongovernment and community-based organizations) so that 
they can coordinate, build synergies, and pool resources for better development outcomes. Finally, 
the TA will help the PMO collect video footage to document the redevelopment progress in ger 
areas, for use in decision making and public relations. 

 
Design and monitoring framework. The TA will enhance the quality of outputs  under 
13. 
Tranche  1  without  any  change  to  its  targeted  results  indicators.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework of Tranche 1 thus remains unchanged. 
 
C. 

Cost and Financing 

14. 
The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
15. 
Ineligible expenditure. The fund will not be used for (i) civil  works, (ii) procurement of 
large-scale  equipment,  (iii)  permanent  staffing  costs,  or  (iv)  hiring  of  staff  consultants,  unless 
otherwise agreed between the Republic of Korea and ADB. 
 
16. 
supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D. 

The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office

18. 
Consulting services. ADB will engage an individual consultant and a consulting firm in 
accordance  with  the  ADB Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the 
associated  project  administration  instructions/TA  staff  instructions.  The  individual  international 
consultant will be engaged using the individual consultant selection method, for a total of 6 person-
months. The consulting firm will be engaged using quality- and cost-based selection method, with 
a  90:10  quality-cost  ratio  and  using  simplified  technical  proposal  procedures,  for  a  total  of 
38 person-months of consulting inputs (5 person-months of international and 33 person-months 
of  national  inputs).5 The  firm  must  demonstrate  international  expertise  and  local  experience  in 
Mongolia.  
 
19. 
ADB Procurement. Three shopping contracts for a total of $120,000 will be procured by 
the consultants. All TA-financed goods shall be procured in accordance with ADB Procurement 
Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the  associated  Project  Administration 
Instructions/TA Staff Instructions.

III. 

THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  

21. 
The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of  Mongolia  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge 
Partnership Fund for Ulaanbaatar Pro-Poor Urban Redevelopment Support System for Ger Areas, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.
